SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Anslow, Herbert Arthur E.
Stony Beach.

To Sask. - April, 1891

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has traced all the facts and experiences as accurately as possible. Some of the questions here will not apply to your particular experience. Others may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about them. If there is any extra sheet of paper, or if there is not sufficient space on the questionnaire itself, feel free to use it to give details, or describe particular events in more detail.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and are willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires' conditions:
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Retention of questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatoon, Sask.
PIONEER BIOGRAPHIES & GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Herbert Arthur Edward Andrew
2. Your address: Story Beach Ranch
3. Date: June 9, 1943
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Staffordshire, England.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Arthur Andrew, merchant
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) April 1891
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   A very young boy
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   My father wanted to farm
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information)?
    C.P.R. advertising
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Opinions were mixed.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

With friends

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Boat and rail

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

I remember a very bad storm on the Atlantic a few days after we left Liverpool.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Regina

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

County of North West of Regina

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Except for short periods have lived only in Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
My parents wrote frequently.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
Myrtle Grace Browland
At Regina July 27 1916

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
All others were born in Sask.
and live near Regina.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
I remember most the terrible blizzards in the winters, the prairie fires and thunder storms in summers.
And once I remember hiding from a travelling band of Blackfoot Indians.
Almost forgot to mention the mosquitoes.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
We travelled by horse and bush boat.
3. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

My parents wrote frequently.

20. If not married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

My wife, Mary Ann, married July 9, 1916

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it was a place to settle?

I believe others came from in Pard.

and live in near Regina.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West will you mention their names?

I believe they came from the prairies.

23. In what way particularly do you consider the advantages of the settlement?

The climate is very healthy.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far?

We traveled by horse and buckboard.
25. When was the first car used in the community? In 1911

26. If you owned a car before 1911, when did you buy it? What make?
   In 1911 it was a Model T Ford.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Quinsigamond, 8 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? About once a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   Monthly after the introduction of cars.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   Right from the start.
   We used to order from Toronto.
   Sometimes the neighbors would pool their orders to reduce freight charges.
   It was always a big day for our kids when the "Cater Box" arrived.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   About 1908, Maclean Rural Tel Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Speaking for my father I know he intended to stay if possible.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1943? What reasons did they have for moving?

Although few did many would have had they the means to do so.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return? No.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My father, Arthur Rossiter was always active in various organizations being at various times connected with: Patrons of Industry, M.E. A. Lincoln County, Elks Club, M.E.A. Agricultural Society, Wascona School Board. He was Justice of the Peace for about forty years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

We owned one of the first two Ford cars in the district.

We had the first gasoline trucking outfit in the district.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in name since the first name was given; date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Wascona District: From the Indian word meaning pile of bones (buffalo)

School district, original post office, creek, and the city of Regina itself were all called Wascona.

Cold Grooving: When the Hudson Bay traders crossed the Wascona valley on their trek from Fort Garry to Edmonton. This river was extremely cold in fall.

Mechanization of farming,
telephones, cars radios etc.
